full_text:
Hi Frank,

I'd love it if you could take a look at it for us so you give us  
guidance, we're not experienced at this type of stuff and I'd feel  
much better if we were shown what /where/how. We don't want to  
interrupt your holiday, but if you're not a big New Years fan even 10  
minutes of your time would be great.

If you're still willing to take a look, where would you like to  meet?  
You can give me a call, the number below is my home business. Don't  
know where in Littleton you are, but I usually meet clients at the  
Starbucks in Aspen Grove. There's another Starbucks at Broadway &  
Littleton Blvd. I'd  need to make sure they're open today.

If you're busy, I understand. We'll just do our best!

On Dec 31, 2007, at 7:37 PM, Frank Sumption wrote:

> It's farily straight forward to repair, you can tell what conductor
> goes to what conductor on the board. It's just a matter of making
> little jumpers with small wire to bridge the breaks. Radio shack has
> #30 wire wrap wire that works well for that kind of stuff. Maybe
> there's enough of the original pad left on the connectors that you
> could glue them back in place, then jumper the breaks. I could look
> at it tomorrow, as well.
>
>


>  There's a green coating on the circuit traces called solder mask,  
> you'll have to very gently scrap some of the mask off to solder on a  
> jumper wire. You'll see the copper colored conductor under the mask.  
> Then you aplly some solder to conductor, and some to the wire, then  
> heat the two togther to join them. Watch out for solder bridges  
> between conductors.
>
>

> Frank-S
